A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any others. Some will be glad to answer every question; others may not be able to answer all of them. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Train from Saint John to Stan Betsy 25 miles by ocean and stagecoach.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Stormy passage, sickness, floating ice, our luggage went astray for 6 weeks, 2 friends on train, one was caught, had to leave train at Burnt Maw. Arrived at Star City by construction train on April 4th.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Stayed at Ole Olson's and John Quinell's 2 miles west of Star City until we received our luggage then we moved to the homestead cut holes down around them built a shack to live in.

If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, did they come here 18 months before the rest of the family came out, all settled here, but have drifted away to other occupations in Canada, one went to New Yearland, I am the only one remaining on our original homestead.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Living on the north side of the Board River we had plenty of experience when the water was high, on our first trip up to the homestead the waggon struck a large rock in five feet of water, chain the ox harness broke, so we had to get in the water, chain the other ox back and he drew the load out alone. One day one of the oxen fell down a steep cliff and died, so we hitched our bull with the other ox, and after he turned down, we rode him through the river to get our mail from the Post Office four miles south.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

We had to walk on to the Oden and Stadel, once I drove them to 7 miles north of Moffatt which took nearly a week on those hard roads. Church was 7 miles away; our nearest neighbour's church was 14 miles away; we had to make our own roads only the snowshoes were cut.
